questions.text: Calculate the percentage of burns in a 6-year-old child whose head and neck was burnt in an accident at school? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 18%

 

As per Lund and Browder chart the percentage of burns in this child would be 18%.

 

For the 1-9 years age group, the Lund-Browder chart is divided into the following regions:

 

  1. Head and Neck: 18%
  2. Anterior Trunk: 18%
  3. Posterior Trunk: 18%
  4. Each Arm: 9%
  5. Each Leg: 14%
  6. Perineum: 1%

 

The Lund-Browder chart is a tool used to estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) of burns in paediatric patients. It is divided into regions that correspond to different percentages of TBSA, and each region is assigned a different percentage based on the age of the patient. The chart takes into account the fact that the proportion of body surface area represented by different body parts changes as a child grows.

 

The chart is divided into three age groups: 0-1 year, 1-9 years, and 9-17 years. Each age group has its own chart with different regions and percentages. The regions are further divided into sub-regions to allow for more accurate estimation of the TBSA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9%: For a 6-year-old child, 9% represents the TBSA of each arm. This does not correspond to the head and neck region.

 

Option C. 27%: There is no single region in the Lund-Browder chart for the 1-9 years age group that accounts for 27% of the TBSA. The head and neck alone are 18%.

 

Option D. 36%: This percentage does not correspond to any single region or combination of the head and neck in the Lund-Browder chart for a child of this age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the Lund and Browder chart is essential for accurately assessing burn injuries in pediatric patients.
  • For children aged 1-9 years, the head and neck region accounts for 18% of the TBSA.
  • This knowledge is crucial for determining the appropriate treatment and management of burn injuries in children.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs work as an antagonist of NMDA receptors? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ketamine

 

Ketamine is a well-known NMDA receptor antagonist. It binds to the NMDA receptor, blocking the action of glutamate, an excitatory neurotransmitter. This blockade of NMDA receptors contributes to Ketamine's unique dissociative anesthetic effects, analgesia, and other clinical applications.

 

Mnemonic

 

  • K - Kids: preferred anaesthetic agent in pediatric patients.
  • E - Emergency Reaction: CNS side effects during recovery.
  • T – Thalamocortical junction responsible for dissociative anesthesia, a primary characteristic of ketamine.
  • A - Analgesic. Known as the most potent analgesic among anesthetic agents.
  • M - Meals: Can be administered even with a full stomach, unlike many anesthetics.
  • I - ↑BP/↑IOP/↑ICP: Indicates that ketamine can increase blood pressure (BP), intraocular pressure (IOP), and intracranial pressure (ICP).
  • N - NMDA Antagonist: The primary mechanism of action for ketamine, blocking NMDA receptors which is crucial in its role as an anesthetic.
  • E – Excellent Bronchodilator

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midazolam: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine, a class of drugs that enhance the inhibitory effects of GABA. It does not interact directly with NMDA receptors.

 

Option C. Propofol: Propofol primarily acts by enhancing the activity of GABA receptors. It does not have any significant antagonist action at NMDA receptors.

 

Option D. Thiopentone: Thiopentone is a barbiturate that also works by enhancing GABAergic transmission. It lacks any direct antagonist effect on NMDA receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NMDA Antagonist drugs: (Mnemonic – Kill NMDA Receptors)

 

  • K – Ketamine & S-ketamine
  • N - Nitrous Oxide
  • M - Memantine
  • D - Dextromethorphan
  • A - Amantadine
  • R - Riluzole

questions.text: During the anthropometric evaluation, the height for age of a child is < - 2D. This is most likely due to? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic malnutrition

 

If the height for age of a child is less than -2 standard deviations (SD) from the median of the reference population, it is most likely due to chronic malnutrition.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Chronic Malnutrition (Stunting): Chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, occurs when a child does not receive adequate nutrition over a prolonged period, especially during the critical first 1,000 days of life (from conception to the child's second birthday). This results in impaired linear growth, making the child shorter than expected for their age. Height for age is the key indicator used to measure stunting.
  • Acute Malnutrition (Wasting): Acute malnutrition, or wasting, is characterized by a rapid loss of weight relative to height. It is usually the result of a recent illness or severe food shortage. Weight for height is the primary measure of wasting, not height for age.
  • Recent Infection: While a recent infection can temporarily affect a child's weight or growth velocity, it does not typically lead to chronic stunting unless the child experiences recurrent infections over a long period.
  • No Malnutrition: If a child's height for age is within the normal range, it indicates adequate nutrition and growth. However, a height for age < -2SD indicates a significant deviation from the norm due to chronic nutritional deficiencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute malnutrition: This condition affects the weight for height parameter, indicating a rapid loss of weight rather than a prolonged deficit in linear growth.

 

Option C. Recent infection: Although a recent infection can cause temporary weight loss or affect growth velocity, it is unlikely to result in stunted growth unless the child has had recurrent infections over an extended period.

 

Option D. No malnutrition: A child with a height for age < -2SD cannot be classified as having no malnutrition, as this deviation indicates chronic nutritional deficiencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Height for age < -2SD is indicative of chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, which results from prolonged inadequate nutrition, particularly during the critical early years of a child's life.

choices.text: It is a type of secondary osteomyelitis

questions.text: Which of the following statements about tubercular osteomyelitis is not true? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Periosteal reaction is characteristic

 

Periosteal reaction is not characteristic of tubercular osteomyelitis. In fact, tubercular osteomyelitis typically presents as a well-defined area of bone destruction with minimal reactive new bone formation. This is distinctly different from pyogenic osteomyelitis where significant periosteal new bone formation is an important feature. The only exception is "Spina Ventosa" (tubercular dactylitis) where periosteal reaction can be seen in the digits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a type of secondary osteomyelitis - This is true. Tubercular osteomyelitis is always secondary to a primary focus elsewhere in the body, commonly in the lungs or lymph nodes. The infection spreads to bone hematogenously.

 

Option B. Sequestrum is uncommon - This is actually true for typical tubercular osteomyelitis. While sequestra can occur, they are less common and less prominent compared to pyogenic osteomyelitis due to the more indolent nature of the infection.

 

Option D. Inflammation is minimal - This is true. Tubercular osteomyelitis causes a chronic granulomatous inflammation rather than the acute suppurative inflammation seen in pyogenic infections. The lesions are paucibacillary (containing few bacteria) with minimal inflammation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Unlike pyogenic osteomyelitis, tubercular osteomyelitis typically presents with well-defined bone destruction, minimal periosteal reaction, less prominent sequestrum formation, and chronic granulomatous inflammation rather than acute suppurative changes.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis in a female with dysuria and vesicles for which she underwent an examination that revealed the presence of cells as shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex virus

 

The image shown is a Tzanck smear, which is often used to diagnose infections caused by herpes viruses. The Tzanck smear reveals characteristic nuclear changes, including nuclear molding, margination of chromatin, and multinucleated giant cells, which are hallmark findings in herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections.

 

Patients with HSV typically present with vesicular lesions on the genitalia accompanied by dysuria and pain. The infection involves the fusion of epithelial cells, leading to the appearance of multinucleated giant cells, a distinctive feature seen on Tzanck smears.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomoniasis: Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. It presents with frothy discharge and vaginal itching but does not produce vesicular lesions or the cytological features seen in HSV.

 

Option C. Human papilloma virus (HPV): HPV causes genital warts and is associated with cervical dysplasia and cancer. It does not produce vesicular lesions or characteristic changes like multinucleated giant cells seen in HSV.

 

Option D. Cytomegalovirus: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections are characterized by large cells with prominent intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions, often described as "owl's eye" appearance. This differs from the nuclear molding and margination seen in HSV infections.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes simplex virus infection is identified by multinucleated giant cells, nuclear molding, and margination on Tzanck smear, distinguishing it from other genital infections.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with palpitations and giddiness. Her blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. ECG shows absent P waves and an irregularly irregular RR interval. What is the next step in management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cardioversion

 

Explanation:

 

This is a case of atrial fibrillation (AF) with hemodynamic instability. The diagnosis is supported by:

 

  • ECG findings of absent P waves and an irregularly irregular RR interval – Classic for AF
  • Low blood pressure (80/60 mmHg) – Indicates hemodynamic compromise
  • Symptoms of palpitations and giddiness – Suggest compromised cardiac output

 

In any tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability (systolic BP < 90 mmHg), immediate synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice, regardless of the specific arrhythmia. This is because unstable blood pressure indicates that the patient is in shock and requires immediate rhythm restoration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenosine: Incorrect

 

  • Used primarily for PSVT (Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia)
  • Not effective in atrial fibrillation (in fact C/I !!)

 

Option B. Verapamil: Incorrect

 

  • Useful in rate control for stable AF
  • Contraindicated in hypotensive patients as it can worsen hypotension
  • Reserved for hemodynamically stable patients

 

Option C. Amiodarone: Incorrect

 

  • Effective for AF, but has a delayed onset of action
  • Not appropriate when immediate rhythm restoration is needed due to instability
  • Better suited for maintenance therapy or rhythm control in stable patients

 

Educational Objective:

 

In tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability (systolic BP < 90 mmHg), immediate synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice, regardless of the specific arrhythmia type.

questions.text: Which of the following is the pattern of inheritance with the pedigree chart provided in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mitochondrial inheritance

 

The pedigree chart provided in the image demonstrates a pattern of inheritance where an affected female passes the trait or disease to all of her offspring, regardless of their gender. Additionally, the affected males do not pass the trait to any of their offspring. This pattern is characteristic of mitochondrial inheritance, also known as maternal inheritance.

 

Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is inherited exclusively from the mother because mitochondria in the sperm are typically not involved in fertilization. Therefore, any mutations in mitochondrial DNA will be passed from an affected mother to all of her children. However, because males do not contribute mitochondria to their offspring, they do not pass on mitochondrial diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal recessive: Autosomal recessive inheritance typically requires both parents to carry one copy of the mutated gene, and it affects both males and females equally. The pattern in the pedigree, where all children of an affected female are affected, does not fit an autosomal recessive pattern.

 

Option B. Autosomal dominant: Autosomal dominant inheritance usually involves a 50% chance of passing the mutated gene from an affected parent to each child, regardless of gender. The pedigree showing all offspring of an affected female being affected, while none of the offspring of an affected male are affected, does not fit this pattern.

 

Option C. X-linked recessive: X-linked recessive inheritance usually affects males more frequently, as they have only one X chromosome. Affected males would pass the mutated gene to all of their daughters (who would be carriers) but none of their sons. This pattern does not match the pedigree chart provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by the transmission of a trait from an affected mother to all of her offspring, while affected males do not pass the trait to their children. This unique pattern is due to the inheritance of mitochondrial DNA, which is maternally inherited.

 

Example of Maternal/ mitochondrial inheritance diseases: Leber's Optic Neuropathy, MELAS Syndrome (Mitochondrial Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like manifestation).

questions.text: Which family member is responsible for transmission of the disease in mitochondrial inheritance? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mother

 

Mitochondrial inheritance follows a maternal pattern of transmission. This is because the mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is exclusively transmitted from the mother to all her children. During fertilization, the sperm contributes its nuclear DNA but its mitochondria are destroyed, so all mitochondria in the zygote come from the egg. This results in what is known as maternal inheritance, where diseases caused by mutations in mitochondrial DNA are transmitted only through the mother.

 

  • Examples
    • MELAS → Mitochondrial Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, Stroke
    • Leigh's Disease
    • NARP SYNDROME → Neuropathy, Ataxia, Retinitis Pigmentosal
    • Leber's Optic Neuropathy
  • Mitochondrial DNA is present in ovum & not in sperms

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grandfather (maternal): Incorrect. Though the maternal grandfather carries mitochondrial DNA, he cannot transmit it to his grandchildren. His daughters receive his nuclear DNA but their mitochondrial DNA comes from their mother (the maternal grandmother).

 

Option B. Grandfather (paternal): Incorrect. The paternal grandfather's mitochondrial DNA is not transmitted to his son, and consequently not to his grandchildren.

 

Option C. Father: Incorrect. Although the father contributes half of the nuclear DNA to the child, he does not contribute any mitochondrial DNA, as paternal mitochondria are destroyed after fertilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial inheritance follows a maternal transmission pattern in which only mothers can pass mitochondrial DNA mutations to their children. This occurs because all mitochondria in humans are inherited from the mother's egg cell, while paternal mitochondria are eliminated during fertilization.

questions.text: Which one of the following leads to shift toward red curve in the given graph? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acidosis

 

Explanation: 

 

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve (OHDC) shows the relationship between PO2 and hemoglobin saturation. The red curve in the image represents a right shift. Acidosis causes a right shift of the curve, known as the Bohr effect. When blood pH decreases (acidosis), the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen decreases, causing more oxygen to be released to the tissues. This is physiologically beneficial as tissues in acidotic conditions often need more oxygen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Less 2,3 BPG: Incorrect Less 2,3-BPG causes a left shift of the curve, not right

 

  • When 2,3-BPG levels decrease, hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen increases
  • This means oxygen binds more tightly to hemoglobin and less is released to tissues

 

Option C. Hypocarbia: Incorrect Hypocarbia means decreased CO2 levels

 

  • This leads to alkalosis which causes a left shift
  • Results in increased affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen

 

Option D. Hypothermia: Incorrect Lower temperature causes a left shift of the curve

 

  • Increases hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen
  • Reduces oxygen delivery to tissues

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acidosis causes a right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve (Bohr effect), while alkalosis, hypothermia, and decreased 2,3-BPG cause left shifts.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Pompholyx is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Most common site is soles

 

  • Pompholyx (also known as dyshidrotic eczema or vesicular eczema) is characterized by intensely pruritic and painful deep-seated vesicles that have a sago grain-like appearance. 
  • These vesicles typically occur at the sides of digits rather than primarily on the soles. 
  • The most common sites are the fingers and palms, with soles being affected sometimes but not as the primary or most common location.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sago-grain like vesicles - This is correct. 

  • Pompholyx lesions have a characteristic "sago grain-like appearance" which refers to their deep-seated vesicular presentation.

 

 

 

Option C. Pruritus may precede eruption - This is correct. 

  • Pompholyx is described as "intensely pruritic" and itching is a hallmark symptom that can occur before visible lesions appear.

 

Option D. Symmetric distribution - This is correct. 

  • Pompholyx typically presents with symmetric distribution, affecting both hands or both feet in a similar pattern.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Pompholyx is characterized by intensely pruritic deep-seated vesicles with sago grain-like appearance occurring primarily on fingers and palms, less commonly on soles, and typically presents with symmetric distribution.

questions.text: A PLHIV with low CD4 count admitted with pneumonia. GMS stain of BAL shown in the image. Choose the correct agent: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumocystis

 

The image provided shows a GMS stain of BAL (Bronchoalveolar lavage) fluid, which is a common diagnostic method used to identify pathogens in patients with pneumonia. The patient is HIV-positive with a low CD4 count, indicating immunocompromise. Pneumocystis jirovecii is a common cause of pneumonia in such patients, often referred to as Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). The hallmark appearance of Pneumocystis in a GMS stain is the black, crushed ping-pong ball-like cysts against a green background, which is visible in the image.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptococcus: Cryptococcus usually appears as encapsulated yeast cells, often seen in India ink preparations or mucicarmine stains. It does not show the crushed ping-pong ball appearance seen in the image.

 

Option B. Mucor: Mucor species are identified by their broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, typically visible on H&E or PAS stains, not GMS. The morphology seen in the image does not match Mucor.

 

Option D. Candida: Candida typically appears as budding yeast and pseudohyphae, which do not resemble the crushed ping-pong ball appearance shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii is a common cause of pneumonia in HIV patients with low CD4 counts and is identified by its characteristic crushed ping-pong ball appearance in GMS-stained samples.

choices.text: It is a dystonia of the laryngeal muscles.
Standard treatment is with injection of Botulinum Toxin.
Multiple injections of Botulinum toxin are required.
Patients with Abductor Type Dysphonia have a strained and strangled voice.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about spasmodic dysphonia is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Patients with Abductor Type Dysphonia have a strained and strangled voice.

 

Explanation:


This statement is incorrect because patients with Abductor Type Dysphonia actually present with a breathy voice or breathy breaks in voice, not a strained and strangled voice. The strained or strangled voice quality with phonation interruptions and voice breaks is characteristic of Adductor Dysphonia, where the adductor muscles of the larynx go into spasm causing vocal cords to adduct excessively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a dystonia of the laryngeal muscles. This is true. Spasmodic dysphonia involves abnormal muscular contractions (spasms) of the laryngeal muscles during speech. The condition can involve either adductor or abductor muscles, causing different voice patterns.

 

Option B. Standard treatment is with injection of Botulinum Toxin. This is true. Botulinum toxin injections are the standard treatment for both adductor and abductor spasmodic dysphonia. In adductor type, injections target the thyroarytenoid muscle, while in abductor type, the posterior cricoarytenoid muscles are injected.

 

Option C. Multiple injections of Botulinum toxin are required. This is true. The benefit of botulinum toxin injections typically lasts only up to 16 weeks, after which repeat injections are needed. This makes it a recurring treatment rather than a one-time solution.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Adductor and Abductor spasmodic dysphonias present with distinctly different voice qualities - strained/strangled in adductor type versus breathy in abductor type - though both are treated with botulinum toxin injections that require periodic repetition due to their temporary effect.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was brought with bow legs and on x-ray of wrist, following were the findings. The child also had low serum calcium and low serum phosphate values. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rickets

 

  • Vitamin-D, calcium, and phosphorus are the main factors that influence bone maturation and mineralization. 
  • Defective mineralization can lead to rickets and/or osteomalacia. 
  • Rickets is characterized by a defect in mineralization and the widening of the epiphyseal plates.
  • Rickets occurs exclusively in children.
  • Nutritional rickets is the most common cause of bone disease.
  • Vitamin D deficiency is the most common cause of nutritional rickets.
  • Any defect in osteoid mineralization may cause rickets.
  • In all types of rickets, the characteristic features occur at the growth plate. 
  • In rickets, the calcium level is either normal or low; phosphate levels are low; and ALP and PTH are high.
  • The potential lower limb deformities include bow legs (genu varus), knock knees (genu valgus), and joints (knees and ankles) swelling, whereas the deformities of the upper limbs include the wrist widening.
  • The ulna grows relatively rapidly and hence, it is significantly affected.
  • The characteristic radiographic features of rickets are thickening and widening of growth plate (physis), indistinct and hazy metaphysis that is abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance), bowing of diaphysis with thinning of cortices.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scurvy: Scurvy is a condition caused by dietary lack of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), hence is also called hypovitaminosis C. It is characterized by an increased bleeding tendency, impaired collagen synthesis resulting in osteoporosis, and impaired wound healing. It is rarely seen in adults. Young children and elderly are more predisposed to scurvy due to diet or overheating of food. It does not occur before 6 months of age. Patients present with lethargy, malaise, bone pain, bleeding diathesis, and impaired wound healing. Pediatric radiographic features include generalized osteopenia, cortical thinning (pencil-point cortex), periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage, expansion of costochondral junctions (scorbutic rosary), hemarthrosis, Wimberger ring sign (circular, opaque shadow around epiphyseal centers of ossification, due to bleeding). 

 

 

Option C. Hypophosphatemia: Hypophosphatemia is defined as an adult serum phosphate level < 2.5 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL). Normal serum phosphate levels in children are considerably higher, 4-7 mg/dL. Hypophosphatemia is a relatively common laboratory abnormality and is often an incidental finding. Most patients with hypophosphatemia are asymptomatic, and the most common symptom is generalized mild to moderate weakness. Clinical symptoms usually appear with moderate or severe hypophosphatemia. Neurologic symptoms include altered mental status, dysarthria, seizures, and numbness or reflexive weakness. Cardiac and respiratory failure can occur in severe cases. In addition to muscle weakness, muscle pain may signify hypophosphatemia-related rhabdomyolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image of the child’s hands and wrists shows cupping and splaying of the radius and the ulna. 
  • The patient presents with bow legs, and decreased levels of serum calcium and phosphate. 
  • These are common findings of rickets caused by defective bone mineralization or nutritional deficiency of vitamin D in children.

questions.text: Which vitamin, when infused in supraphysiological doses, causes macular edema and macular cysts? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin B3

 

Supraphysiological doses of Vitamin B3, also known as Niacin, have been known to cause adverse effects, including macular edema and macular cysts. This side effect is relatively rare but has been documented in some cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to various eye problems, but it is not associated with macular edema and macular cysts caused by supraphysiological doses.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D is essential for various bodily functions, including bone health, but it is not known to cause macular edema or macular cysts.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E is an antioxidant that helps protect cells from damage, but it is not associated with macular edema or macular cysts caused by supraphysiological doses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nicotinic acid when given orally or parenterally produces a transient vasodilatation of the cutaneous vessels and histamine release. The reaction is accompanied by itching, burning and tingling. Intake of nicotinic acid in excess of 50 mg/day may lead to liver damage (Raised AST and ALT levels, Fulminant hepatitis)

 

Niacin causes a reversible toxic cystoid maculopathy that occurs in approximately 0.67% of patients taking high doses of the drug.

 

Other symptoms –

 

  • Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
  • Glucose intolerance (therefore weekly glucose monitoring done if given in diabetics)
  • Hyperuricemia

choices.text: Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor

questions.text: You are examining a multigravida in the second stage of labor for the past two hours. On examination, contractions are adequate, the cervix is fully dilated with the head at station 0 with molding 2+ and caput 2+. The sagittal suture is in the right occipito-transverse position. The fetal heart rate is 140 beats/minute. Which of the following is carried out for the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lower segment cesarean section

 

  • The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of deep transverse arrest (DTA)
  • There are features of CPD (Caput 2 + and moulding 2+)
  • Hence, a lower segment cesarean section is carried out for the management of this patient.
  • In deep transverse arrest
    • The sagittal suture is placed in the transverse bispinous diameter.
    • There is no descent of the head despite good uterine contractions
    • The cervix is fully dilated
    • If the pelvis is adequate, application of ventouse or manual rotation and forces application can be tried. (Vacuum is preferred)
    • If signs of CDP/ obstruction: Cesarean section is done

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mid pelvic forceps: Mid pelvic forceps: Cannot be applied in this scenario as there are features of obstructed labor with deep transverse arrest

 

Option B. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Vacuum is an option in deep transverse arrest but only if there is no CPD. With caput ++ and moulding ++, there is likely an element of CPD and obstruction and hence vacuum should not be used

 

Option C. Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor: Waiting and watching is not an option as the patient is already showing features of obstructed labor and she has already been in 2nd stage of labor for 2 hours (upper limit for 2nd stage of labor in primi is 3h and in multi is 2h)

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case of deep transverse arrest with features of CPD, a lower segment cesarean section is the appropriate management to prevent complications and ensure safe delivery.

 

Ref: Page 661, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: The structure marked A in the image below gives rise to which of the following structures? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Falciform ligament

 

The structure marked A is ventral mesogastrium. The falciform ligament is a derivative of the ventral mesogastrium.

 

 

  • Mesogastriumis double layers of the peritoneum that enclose an organ (stomach) and connect it to the body wall. They provide pathways for vessels, nerves, and lymphatics to and from the abdominal viscera.
  • The ventral mesogastrium: is a structure found only in the foregut and is attached to the terminal part of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper part of the duodenum.
  • It is derived from the septum transversum and is divided into two parts by the growth of the liver into the mesenchyme of the septum transversum.
  • These two parts are the lesser omentum, which extends from the lower portion of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper portion of the duodenum to the liver, and the ligaments of the liver, which include all the liver ligaments except for the ligamentum teres.
  • The Dorsal mesogastrium: The foregut, midgut, and hindgut are connected to the posterior abdominal wall by the Dorsal mesogastrium.
  • The dorsal mesentery extends from the lower end of the esophagus to the cloacal region of the hindgut and has specific names depending on the region it is found in.
    • Dorsal mesogastrium (or greater omentum)- stomach
    • Dorsal mesoduodenum- duodenum
    • Mesentery proper- jejunum and ileum
    • Mesoappendix- appendix
    • Transverse mesocolon- transverse colon

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrosplenic Ligament: It is derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. It's a peritoneal fold that connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen. The short gastric vessels and the left gastroepiploic vessels run within this ligament.

 

Option B. Lienorenal Ligament: It is also derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. This ligament connects the hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney. As with the gastrosplenic ligament, it's a reflection or fold of the peritoneum.

 

Option D. Gastrophrenic Ligament: it is derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. It is the portion of the greater omentum (which also has its origins in the dorsal mesogastrium) that attaches the stomach to the diaphragm. It's a reflection or fold of the peritoneum that connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Falciform Ligament is derived from the ventral mesogastrium. This sickle-shaped ligament runs from the anterior abdominal wall to the liver, effectively connecting the liver to the diaphragm and anterior abdominal wall. The ligamentum teres (remnant of the umbilical vein) runs within the free edge of this ligament.

questions.text: Identify the most probable age of the child under POCSO (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) Act by looking at the X-ray below:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 7 years

 

  • The X-ray shows 7 Carpal bones. Thus, minimum age is 5 here.
  • Also, pisiform is not seen. Hence, the age is between 5-12.
  • The best answer is 7 years as the normal age range for appearance of pisiform is 8-12 years.

 

BONE AGE

 

  • Left hand and wrist X-ray PA view – most commonly used for bone age assessment – Based on appearance of carpal bones
  • First to appear is Capitate, then in a counter-clockwise fashion except pisiform which is the last carpal bone to appear
  • Pisiform is ossified at the age of nine to 13 years as evident from different studies.
  • The appearance of ossification center of pisiform bone is one of the important evidence for estimating age among young children between nine to 13 years.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The x-ray shown in the image suggests the age of the child to be 7 years as the x-ray does not have the Pisiform bone.
  • Pisiform bone ossifies by the age of 13.

choices.text: E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
E1: Pyruvate Decarboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase
E1: Pyruvate carboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

questions.text: This multienzyme complex converts Pyruvate to Acetyl CoA. Identify E1 and E2: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

 

Explanation:

 

The provided images depict the components and functioning of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, a key multienzyme complex in the metabolic pathway that converts pyruvate into acetyl-CoA, an essential step linking glycolysis to the citric acid cycle. This complex requires vitamins B1, B2, B3, B5, and lipoic acid as cofactors.

 

Table: Components of PDH complex and their roles

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyruvate Decarboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as Pyruvate Decarboxylase is not involved in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in this context, and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase is the E3 component of the complex.

 

Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase: Incorrect because Pyruvate carboxylase is involved in a different metabolic pathway (gluconeogenesis), not in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.

 

Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as the second enzyme is E3 in this complex, not E2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 162

questions.text: What will be the duration of below-knee POP cast applied for the following injury?(NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6-8 weeks

 

For injuries like the one shown in the X-ray (fracture at the base of the fifth metatarsal), the typical treatment involves immobilization using a plaster of Paris (POP) cast. Foot injuries, including fractures of the metatarsal bones, usually require a period of 6-8 weeks to allow for proper healing. This timeframe is standard for most metatarsal fractures, ensuring that the bone has adequate time to heal and regain strength. Specifically, fractures like the Jones fracture (involving the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction) or the Pseudojones fracture (avulsion fracture) are commonly immobilized for this duration.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fractures of the metatarsals, including those at the base of the fifth metatarsal, are typically treated with a below-knee plaster cast for a duration of 6-8 weeks to ensure proper healing.

questions.text: A patient admitted with 50% burns develops an infection at the burn site. The swab was cultured, the isolate is a strict aerobe and the test that is shown in the image is positive. What is the likely etiology of the burn infection? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of infection in the case of a burn. The given image shows a positive oxidase test. Psuedomonas aeruginosa is a strict aerobe and shows a positive oxidase reaction.

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (Red), pyomelanin (Brown).

 

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

 

  • ﻿﻿Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • ﻿﻿Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • ﻿﻿Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • ﻿﻿Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, occurring after hot tub exposure
  • ﻿﻿Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric disease, sepsis with invasive disease.
  • ﻿﻿Ecthyma gangrenosum

 

Pathogenesis - It is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth in a nutrient agar showing green coloured colonies are shown in the image below.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Klebsiella: While also a common hospital-acquired pathogen, it is typically associated with respiratory and urinary tract infections, not specifically burns.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli: Commonly causes gastrointestinal and urinary infections but is not typically associated with burn infections.

 

Option D. Salmonella: Known for causing gastrointestinal infections, not burn wound infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in a burn wound infection is crucial due to its potential for rapid spread and resistance to treatment. Early detection and aggressive management are key to preventing severe complications such as sepsis or further tissue damage.

 

Oxidase test can be used to distinguish organisms by detecting the presence or absence of a respiratory enzyme, cytochrome oxidase. Cytochrome oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of reduced cytochrome by oxygen. Enterobacteriacee (Klebsiella, E. coli, Salmonella) are oxidase negative.

 

Oxidase positive organisms:

 

  • ﻿﻿Pseudomonas
  • ﻿﻿Vibrio
  • ﻿﻿Helicobacter
  • ﻿﻿Campylobacter
  • ﻿﻿Pasteurella
  • ﻿﻿Legionella
  • ﻿﻿Neisseria
  • ﻿﻿Brucella
  • ﻿﻿Moraxella
  • ﻿Burkholderia

questions.text: In a cohort study done in a community, out of those 100 vaccinated for malaria, only 6 developed the disease. At the same time, out of those 100 non-vaccinated, a total of 12 developed the disease. Find the relative risk in the study:  (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.5

 

To find the relative risk (RR) in this study, we first need to calculate the incidence of the disease in both the vaccinated (exposed) and non-vaccinated (non-exposed) groups.

 

Step 1: Incidence in the vaccinated group (exposed):

 

  • Number of vaccinated individuals = 100
  • Number of vaccinated individuals who developed the disease = 6
  • Incidence in the vaccinated group = 6/100 = 0.06

 

Step 2: Incidence in the non-vaccinated group (non-exposed):

 

  • Number of non-vaccinated individuals = 100
  • Number of non-vaccinated individuals who developed the disease = 12
  • Incidence in the non-vaccinated group = 12/100 = 0.12

 

Step 3: Calculate Relative Risk (RR):
 

  • RR = Incidence in the exposed group / Incidence in the non-exposed group
  • RR = 0.06 / 0.12 = 0.5

 

The relative risk of 0.5 indicates that the vaccinated individuals were half as likely to develop malaria compared to those who were not vaccinated. This suggests a protective effect of the vaccine against malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a cohort study, the relative risk is calculated by comparing the incidence of the outcome in the exposed group to the incidence in the non-exposed group.

 

A relative risk less than 1 indicates a protective effect of the exposure, as seen in this example where vaccination reduced the risk of malaria.

questions.text: A Mediterranean person receive primaquine. Which pathway is affected by G-6-PD enzyme deficiency?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HMP pathway

 

This is the correct pathway affected by G6PD enzyme deficiency. G6PD is an enzyme crucial for the proper functioning of the HMP pathway. Deficiency in G6PD can lead to hemolysis (breakdown of red blood cells) in response to oxidative stress, as the HMP pathway is responsible for generating reducing equivalents (NADPH) necessary to protect cells from oxidative damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycolysis: G6PD deficiency primarily affects the HMP pathway, not glycolysis. Glycolysis is a separate metabolic pathway involved in the breakdown of glucose for energy production.

 

Option C. Gluconeogenesis: G6PD deficiency does not directly affect gluconeogenesis. Gluconeogenesis is the metabolic pathway responsible for producing glucose from non-carbohydrate sources, and it does not rely on the G6PD enzyme.

 

Option D. Krebs cycle: G6PD deficiency does not directly affect the Krebs cycle (also known as the citric acid cycle or TCA cycle). The Krebs cycle is involved in the oxidative metabolism of acetyl-CoA, and G6PD deficiency primarily impacts the earlier steps of glucose metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD is the first and rate limiting enzyme of HMP pathway which is the major source of NADPH that is required for reduced glutathione generation and help reduce oxidative stress by neutralizing free radicals.

 

Primaquine is an antimalarial drug and causes oxidative stress. In patients with Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, primaquine can cause hemolysis so it is avoided.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 182

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Chiari malformation

 

Chiari malformation is diagnosed by the presence of tonsillar herniation below the foramen magnum. In the given image, the cerebellar tonsils are seen herniating more than 5 mm below the line drawn between the basion (the lower part of the clivus) and the opisthion (the lower part of the occiput), which is characteristic of Chiari I malformation. This displacement of the tonsils is known as tonsillar ectopia, a hallmark feature of Chiari malformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dandy Walker malformation: This condition is characterized by an enlarged posterior fossa, a posterior fossa cyst, and agenesis of the cerebellar vermis, none of which are seen in the provided image. Therefore, Dandy Walker malformation is not the correct diagnosis.

 

Option C. Vein of Galen malformation: This malformation presents as a large midline vascular structure, typically a signal void due to the dilated vein, which is absent in the provided image. The lack of these vascular changes rules out Vein of Galen malformation.

 

Option D. Encephalocele: Encephaloceles are characterized by herniation of brain tissue through a defect in the skull. There is no evidence of brain tissue protruding from the skull in the image, ruling out encephalocele.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chiari malformation is diagnosed by the inferior displacement of the cerebellar tonsils below the foramen magnum, typically more than 5 mm, seen on imaging.

questions.text: How much is the distance between the victim and the firearm from the gunshot entry based on the wound given below? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Close Contact

 

The image provided shows a gunshot wound with visible tattooing (stippling) around the wound. Tattooing is caused by the impact of unburnt gunpowder particles striking the skin. In close contact range wounds, singeing, blackening, and tattooing are typically seen around the wound, indicating the gun was fired from a very short distance, but not directly pressed against the skin.

 

In this question, since tattooing is visible around the wound without evidence of singeing or blackening directly at the wound margins, it aligns with characteristics of a close contact shot. Ideally, if "Intermediate Range" was an option, it would fit better because it specifically involves tattooing without other signs like singeing and blackening; however, given the choices, close contact remains the most appropriate answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contact Entry: In contact range, the muzzle of the firearm is directly against the skin, causing blackening, singeing, and tattooing only at the margins of the wound, not around it. This differs from what is seen in the image, ruling this option out.

 

Option C. Distant Range: In distant range wounds, there are no signs of singeing, blackening, or tattooing around the entry wound, as the gunpowder does not reach the skin. The presence of tattooing makes this answer incorrect.

 

Option D. Cannot be predicted: This option is incorrect because the presence of tattooing around the wound provides specific information about the distance between the firearm and the victim, allowing us to make an informed decision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tattooing (stippling) around a gunshot wound indicates a close contact or intermediate range. The absence of singeing or blackening suggests the firearm was not in direct contact but was fired from a short distance, such as close contact.

questions.text: Identify the following sign: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tear drop sign

 

Explanation: 


The image shows the tear drop sign (also called hanging drop sign) because:

 

  • Shows herniation of orbital contents into maxillary sinus
  • Appears as a tear-shaped shadow on imaging
  • Characteristic finding in orbital floor fractures (blow-out fractures)
  • Occurs due to disruption of orbital floor allowing downward displacement of orbital contents
  • Important radiological sign in trauma cases

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Steeple sign

 

  • Seen in croup
  • Shows subglottic narrowing on AP view
  • Appears as narrowing of upper airway
  • Different radiological appearance

 

 

Option C. Thumb sign

 

  • Seen in acute epiglottitis
  • Shows swollen epiglottis on lateral neck X-ray
  • Appears as thumb-like shadow
  • Different anatomical location

 

 

Option D. Sail sign

 

  • Not a commonly used radiological sign in ENT
  • Different appearance and location
  • Not related to orbital or sinus pathology

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Recognize the tear drop sign (hanging drop sign) as characteristic radiological finding in orbital floor fractures showing herniation of orbital contents into maxillary sinus
